results.title: Being real about relationships
results.brief_description: In the second half of the Twentieth Century there have been developments in contraception. The film explains the rhythm, the calender, the temperature, the ovulation, the withdrawal, the barrier, the diaphragm, the condom, the IUD, the pill and the sterilisation methods.

results.title: British Mutoscope featuring Charlie Chaplin reel
results.brief_description: The mutoscope was an early motion-picture machine that worked like a flipbook. Instead of continuous prints in a book, the mutoscope’s cards were attached to a reel and the images were animated when you turned a hand crank, much like Thomas Edison’s Kinetoscope.

constellations_primary.name: Perception, time and flickering images
constellations_primary.description: Using a peep hole and a loop of rotating still images, mutoscopes control the point of view of the audience while also creating the illusion of depth. Filmmakers have since put optical tricks to work creating surreal scenes.

results.description: The mutoscope was an early motion-picture machine that worked like a flipbook. Instead of continuous prints in a book, the mutoscope’s cards were attached to a reel and the images were animated when you turned a hand crank, much like Thomas Edison’s Kinetoscope. It was also similar because it didn’t feature projection and only one person could view it at a time. Mutoscope scenes were silent (hence the name) and lasted for one minute. One of the machine’s most famous reels was What the Butler Saw, an early erotic film showing a woman partly undressing as if spied through a keyhole. This reel was so popular that the mutoscope was sometimes known as the ‘What the Butler Saw’ machine.
description_for_label: The mutoscope was an early motion-picture machine that worked like a flipbook. Instead of continuous prints in a book, the mutoscope’s cards were attached to a reel and the images were animated when you turned a hand crank, much like Thomas Edison’s Kinetoscope. It was also similar because it didn’t feature projection and only one person could view it at a time. Mutoscope scenes were silent (hence the name) and lasted for one minute. One of the machine’s most famous reels was What the Butler Saw, an early erotic film showing a woman partly undressing as if spied through a keyhole. This reel was so popular that the mutoscope was sometimes known as the ‘What the Butler Saw’ machine.

results.title: Delivery Dancer's Arc: 0° Receiver
results.brief_description: South Korean artist Ayoung Kim blends cinematic storytelling, videogame technology and science fiction in her mind-bending new work, Deliver Dancer’s Arc: 0° Receiver.

constellations_other.name: Hard sci-fi to cyberpunk
constellations_other.description: Ayoung Kim's practice has been inspired by 'hard' science fiction writers like Greg Egan. Recent sci-fi media using hard sci-fi can be connected back to the beginnings of cyberpunk, a sub-genre of sci-fi.

results.description:
South Korean artist Ayoung Kim blends cinematic storytelling, videogame technology and science fiction in her mind-bending new work, Delivery Dancer’s Arc: 0° Receiver. Drawing on influences that range from Blade Runner (1982)’s techno-futurist cityscapes to an 18th-century Indian astronomical observatory, Kim twists sci-fi tropes into a speculative story rich with otherworldly doubles, interdimensional journeys and colliding worlds.

From a high-octane motorcycle chase through ancient ruins to a cat-and-mouse game down neon streets, an ordinary delivery driver must outrun her enemies and embrace her destiny to save time-keeping traditions across possible worlds. With a dynamic mix of live-action footage, app interfaces, CGI avatars and landscapes powered by game engines, Kim uses the tools of screen culture and our hyper-networked age to question time, productivity and the self.
description_for_label:
South Korean artist Ayoung Kim blends cinematic storytelling, videogame technology and science fiction in her mind-bending new work, Delivery Dancer’s Arc: 0° Receiver. Drawing on influences that range from Blade Runner (1982)’s techno-futurist cityscapes to an 18th-century Indian astronomical observatory, Kim twists sci-fi tropes into a speculative story rich with otherworldly doubles, interdimensional journeys and colliding worlds.

From a high-octane motorcycle chase through ancient ruins to a cat-and-mouse game down neon streets, an ordinary delivery driver must outrun her enemies and embrace her destiny to save time-keeping traditions across possible worlds. With a dynamic mix of live-action footage, app interfaces, CGI avatars and landscapes powered by game engines, Kim uses the tools of screen culture and our hyper-networked age to question time, productivity and the self.

results.title: WipEout 2097 for Sega Saturn
results.material_description: CD-ROM videogame. CD-ROM and manual in Sega Saturn case
results.brief_description: WipEout 2097 is set four decades after its predecessor. The F3600 anti-gravity racing competition from the first game has been replaced by an even faster and more dangerous tournament: the F5000 AG league. The racing and weapon use gameplay from the original WipEout remains the same. The main modes from have also returned, but with the addition of a new Challenge Modes. Completing challenges in this mode rewards the player with faster race speeds, new tracks, and new vehicles.

Completing challenges in this mode rewards the player with faster race speeds, new tracks, and new vehicles.

results.title: WipEout for Sega Saturn
results.material_description: CD-ROM videogame. CD-ROM and manual in Sega Saturn case
results.brief_description:
In the world of WipEout, anti-gravity racing is the world’s most popular sport. Tracks stretch out across the world and research is focused on finding even better and faster race craft. Racing for one of four corporations, the player competes to win the prestigious F3600 Anti-Gravity Racing League. Each corporation’s craft has its own strengths and weaknesses, which are further complicated by the choice of different pilots. Races aren’t simply affairs of speed and manoeuvring. The tracks are littered with weapons and powerups to hinder opponents or aid the player.

The game has three modes. Championship has the player attempting to place in the top three of each class, before proceeding to the next. If a player beats this mode in as the top of the Venom class, Rapier class, with tougher opponents, will be unlocked. Single Race pits the player against a full field of pilots in a single track. Time Trail is like single race, but without weapons.
